Pierrick Roger on starting out as YUSU President

05/10/2022

The president of YUSU talks through his priorities for the next academic year

Image by YUSU

By James Clay

Having been elected last year as President of the University of York Student Union, YUSU, Pierrick Roger sat down with Nouse to discuss his aims for the year ahead and give advice to students who are starting a year with more financial pressure than normal.

When discussing his primary aims as President of YUSU, Pierrick described the cost-of-living crisis for students as â€œthe one issue Iâ€™m most keen to deliver onâ€ due to the challenges that all students are facing with their finances. Another significant aim that Pierrick is hoping to achieve is â€œcutting down barriers and reworking how student democracy works.â€

One idea of his is the concept of a student assembly which will allow all students â€œto bring the things up that they want to and have this direct channel of communication from students to offices.â€ This is a large part of Pierrickâ€™s intention â€œto open lines of communication with Sabbatical Officers, Part Time Officers and the university.â€

Following his convincing election victory during the last academic year, Pierrick highlighted on his manifesto the discontentment that many students have towards First Bus. He even went as far as to propose abolishing the contract between the university and First Bus. Despite this, Pierrick said that â€œI didnâ€™t realise that they are actually listening to what I sayâ€ and that the company is taking on board a few of his ideas. Namely, he mentioned the idea to increase the number of disabled seating from four to six. However, he finished by saying that â€œwe want more engagement, but I have no problem in scrapping the First Bus contact.â€

Rent hikes, both off and on campus are a particular source of concern which Pierrick intends to address. In relation to on campus accommodation, Pierrick was of the view that â€œthe university hasnâ€™t recognised its part in making rent so high.â€ He urged the university to build and adapt â€œmore affordable accommodationâ€ rather than expensive luxuries like the newly built David Kato and Anne Lister colleges.

A considerable problem that Pierrick believes YUSU faces is the lack of awareness that many students have about the activities of YUSU. He told Nouse that â€œwe donâ€™t explain anythingâ€ and that he will try to do better to â€œexplain where we stand and what we doâ€ as â€œit is important to build trust.â€ Over the past few weeks, Pierrick and his fellow sabbatical officers have been â€œthinking about the way in which we personalise things, reaching out to each and every studentâ€ across the university campus.

Opening new lines of communication between YUSU, the university and students is another item high up on his list of priorities. Bearing the need for trust in mind, Pierrick went on to explain the various reforms to the YUSU constitution that he would like to see over the coming year. To take one example, â€œconversations have to be had about adding further aims whether it be sustainability or intersectionality.â€

He also expressed his view that â€œsome of the processes we have to go through require 70 percent approvalâ€ in a vote amongst the student body. In matters relating to constitutional amendments and other YUSU activities, Pierrick believes that a simple majority of 50 percent is more appropriate.

Before being elected as the President of YUSU, Pierrick held the position of Environment and Ethics Officer within YUSU, a job which he described as an â€œawful experienceâ€ due to the lack of engagement he had as a Part Time Officer. Coming originally from Singapore, which is an island nation, Pierrick is very conscious about the impact of climate change and how YUSU and the wider university can help mitigate the worst possible impacts.

Pierrick congratulated former Community and Wellbeing Officer Kelly Balmer for her work in establishing a detailed mandatory consent module in the previous academic year, but he urged that it had to go further as â€œit is not yearly, and you can skip through all the content.â€ It is generally believed that sexual misconduct cases go widely unreported on university campuses which is a problem that Pierrick intends to take very seriously.

On misconduct within YUSU societies more broadly, Pierrick hopes to launch â€œa review into our by-law on misconductâ€ so â€œit is more standardised so when there is misconduct, there is also a consequence.â€ This is in response to a number of incidents over the past academic year, one in particular which led the Debating Society to seriously consider leaving YUSU altogether due to their dissatisfaction with the complaints process.

Taking the interview as an opportunity to express his frustration with the broad university management, Pierrick said that â€œit is very hard to get your voice across when they just donâ€™t understand the issues.â€ This comment was a description of the University of York Executive Board which Pierrick Roger often interacts with through his role as President. He further added that â€œthe university does not know how to organise student events.â€ He used the discontent amongst various societies towards the society stall allocation at the recent open days as an example of this.

Commenting on this government and the politics of today, Pierrick stated his view that â€œif there is one body that I canâ€™t even begin to trust, it is this government.â€ It is for this reason that, despite the demand, Pierrick will not be focused on lobbying for lower tuition fees. â€œMoney is tight right now so I donâ€™t know how we would justify to students running a futile campaignâ€ due to the â€œideological oppositionâ€ of this government towards the idea of reducing or abolishing tuition fees.

Pierrick also raised the issue of how important it is for student unions to engage with one another nationally. In particular, he highlighted YUSUâ€™s involvement with the University of Hull in their efforts to bring down the financial burden that students face across the north of England.

As a final comment to all new freshers starting around this time, Pierrick wanted to express a gesture of welcome and encourage everybody to â€œGet involved in everything we do and please have fun as it is a year of freedom.â€ He also urged every student, whether they are a fresher or not, to engage with the activities of YUSU and the opportunities that YUSU offers over the next academic year.

Pierrick will be in office as YUSU President until July 2023 and can choose to run for re-election in February 2023. His manifesto can be found on the YUSU website, and he can be contacted by email at:Â president@yusu.org Or on Instagram: @yusupresident.
